captions.text:
JAMIE ROBINSON: This is Hell
on Wheels Moto Madness, and
I'm taking part in something.
That's Meatball.
These are vintage bikes.
This is Rideapart.
[CHEERING]

MEATBALL: It's geared toward
someone finding something for

$100 with weeds growing
through it.
And you bring it out.

And you don't have to
be in great shape.
And everybody has fun.
And it's a bunch of buddies.

Steve McQueen, who
had everything--

all the money and could
do anything,
race cars, do whatever--

he chose to ride his
$400 Triumph.

And us guys that don't have any
money, we can do exactly
what he always wanted to do.

And he had all the money
in the world.

We can do exactly what
Steve McQueen did.

MALE SPEAKER 1: I work
with Meatball
over at Hell on Wheels.

We kind of work together on
putting on this stuff and

trying to get all these bikes
running for this one day event
they have every year.

Just trying to tune them up and
get them ready, you know?

JAMIE ROBINSON: So Meatball
is quite a character.

MALE SPEAKER 1: Oh, he's
definitely a personality to be
reckoned with.
RICKMAN: Got a 450 Honda.

You touch the front brake with
one finger on that, you go
over the bars.

This thing here, you grab it
with all four, and it goes
faster, I think.
But a lot of fun.

Lot of good people out here
having a lot of fun.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Tell me, man.
How does that feel?
MALE SPEAKER 2: It sucks.
JAMIE ROBINSON: What sucks?

MALE SPEAKER 2: The feeling
of motocross riding
altogether is bogus.

I like to sit on my couch
and relax and tinker on
motorcycles, not ride them.
But I can barely move my arms.
My bike wouldn't run.
Broke another thing.

In practice, broke
my throttle.

It was stuck wide open
and no back brake.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Tell
me about your bike.

MALE SPEAKER 2: It's one of
Meatball's bikes he loaned me.
It's a 500 Frankenstein bike.
The seat is too high for me.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Sum
up the experience
for me in a few words.
MALE SPEAKER 2: [BLEEP]
awesome.
Right?
I mean, look at it.
I'm riding a piece of [BLEEP]
on a racetrack.

And then all my friends at work,
they-- what did you do?
I watched the racing on TV.
And I go, well, [BLEEP]
off, I raced.

JAMIE ROBINSON: What is it
that attracts you towards
motorcycles?
MALE SPEAKER 3: They're fun.
You get your rush, you know?

It's like you're working
with the machine.

And you're getting the same rush
you get from surfing or

skateboarding or whatever,
driving a fast car, you know?

It's the same deal but
with the bike.
They're smaller.

They're easy to store and
work on, you know?

You can bring them places,
and you can do this.
It's like, I don't know.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Riding a
motorcycle is a very

individual sensation,
isn't it?
MALE SPEAKER 3: Exactly.
It is.
It's like--

JAMIE ROBINSON: A lot of
vibration coming through.
MALE SPEAKER 3: Exactly.
You feel every little thing.

You feel when something
happens to the bike.

You know something's
wrong with it.
You know immediately.

Yeah, it's definitely like--
it sounds corny, but when

you're riding, you're
one with the bike.

MEATBALL: --motorcycle
is very free.
You're in the open air.

You're even freer than
in an airplane.

Airplane, you're
in the cockpit.
So it's very, very free.
It's great.

An explosion between
your legs.

I mean, that's where your
genitals are, you know?

You've got explosions going
on between your legs.

MALE SPEAKER 4: This is
a swap meet special.
I went to the swap meet.

I found a motor, some
front ends.

I got an old speedway bike front
tire, an [INAUDIBLE]
tread pattern in the back.

And you know, for a couple
thousand bucks,
it's a good dirt bike.
And it's a bar-hopper, too.

Well, you just got to grab
a handful of throttle,
pin it to win it.

But then again, there's a few
ruts and things like that.

So you just go for
what you know.
And you win by attrition.

There's a lot of bikes
breaking down.
Get out there.

JAMIE ROBINSON: I'm hoping
to ride something today.

I'm just waiting for somebody to
give me something, and then
I'll go ride it.
MALE SPEAKER 4: Oh.

Well, I've got a bike
in the back, a 490.

JAMIE ROBINSON: As usual,
I'm on the blag.

And this gentleman has
come up trumps.

He has a spare bike in the back
of his truck, and he's
going to let me ride it.

MALE SPEAKER 4: It's already
signed up and stuff, so all

you've got to do is put the
helmet on and the goggles.
JAMIE ROBINSON: No way.
Which race do I take part in?

MALE SPEAKER 4: You're
in the vintage 250.
OK, you're in the next race.
Yeah, they got them 250s up.

JAMIE ROBINSON: That may have
only lasted a few minutes, but
that was epic, man.
Oh, wow.
You've got to try this.

This is vintage motocross
at its best.
There you go, man.
Thank you.

It might have only lasted a few
laps, but that was epic.
Beautiful.

Vintage bikes aplenty, and
I've had so much fun.
Get a motorcycle.
It doesn't matter what it is.
Two wheels and an engine.

If it works, just come on
the dirt and play it.
You will not regret it.

MALE SPEAKER 5: You got a Burly
hat and a Burly banner,
and a Hell on Wheels calendar.

MALE SPEAKER 6: Luscious Lori
from Huntington Beach.
Angie Vandalia from Redmond.
Give her a hand.

Came here by the skin of
her teeth, everybody.

JAMIE ROBINSON: Will you
be back for more?

MALE SPEAKER 7: Oh, definitely,
definitely.
I think I'm hooked now.

JAMIE ROBINSON: What bike
were you riding today?

MALE SPEAKER 8: I'm on
a 1976 Yamaha TT500.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Wow.

And how much did that
cost roughly?

MALE SPEAKER 8: I bought it for
a grand at the Long Beach

swap meet about two months,
maybe three months ago.
But we've been--

for the last four nights,
one of the carburetors--

I think it was the float
needle got stuck.

It's just been draining petrol
into the engine.
And we've been draining it.

I got a new carburetor on it
and got it kicked over last
night super late.
JAMIE ROBINSON: Wow.

MALE SPEAKER 8: It's awesome,
and it's running great.
Oh, man.

I'm so proud of the
motorcycle.
It got through the whole day.

MALE SPEAKER 9: I just
think it's kind of--

I surf and skate as well, and
it's that same kind of
adrenaline rush.

The second you start that bike
up and you twist the throttle,

it's like you forget about all
your worries, and you forget

about all your troubles,
you know?
You just zone in and--

out here, I mean, I'm not the
best racer, but it's just fun

to go as fast as you can and
try to not kill yourself.
Yeah, it's a good time.

MEATBALL: It's very hard to
make something run well or

even something old, where
you can hear each
explosion, you know?
And so, I don't know.

Maybe I just think about it
more and more internally

because I'm inside
it all the time.
But it's what I do.

I think what's going to make
this thing run and how it can
make extra songs sound better.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

comments.text:
I hate the idea of having a motorcycle show on an otherwise car-based 
network (Drive), but I LOVED this show! Fantastic work guys.
comments.author: erichill13

comments.text:
I just kinda noticed, Jamie works his interviews like a sports-media 
person, unlike the "on screen conversation" style that most of the other 
Drive shows use. It worked just fine, and I liked it, I just thought it was 
kind of interesting. I think Jamie needs to keep doing his solo episodes, 
I'd like to see him do something a little less "side-show"ish though. He's 
a great rider, I'd like to hear more of his opinions on bikes.
comments.author: thethePete

comments.text:

car rally (the time rally things), are stuff that I eventually really want 
to do. I want to try the classic car with an Alfa Romeo Spider, and maybe 
find an old Honda 250 for this kind of thing. I'd love it. Really, really 
great stuff.

comments.author: BarryEssex

comments.text:
This kinda thing makes me sick to my stomach..& I've ridden since 81. So we 
have a group of utter losers riding junkyard bikes as fast as they can....A 
liability lawyers dream...With the 'vintage' helmets, poor suspensions, bad 
brakes, fortunate low power...un-skilled riders. A destroyed jaw (Courtesy 
of a vintage helmet) , a errant exploding part...someone is going to lose a 
lifetime of wages for "damages". Anyone attending these "events" should 
turn right around & walk away. Flotsom & Jetsam!
comments.author: RichardEllisxyz

comments.text: Great show
comments.author: MikeZ32TT
